title: Fashion and Myasthenia Gravis

content: Living with myasthenia gravis (MG) has thrown some curveballs my way. But there’s one thing I’ll never let go of --  I’m a girl who’s into fashion, and I plan to keep it that way.
Sure, there are days when my energy is low. But that doesn’t mean I’m ready to swap my style for mismatched loungewear.

Fashion is how I express myself. Just because I deal with a chronic illness doesn’t mean I’m ready to give up on my signature look. Even with MG, I’ve figured out how to balance comfort, accessibility, and style in ways that make me feel fabulous.
Comfort is key, though it doesn’t mean looking frumpy.

I’ve fallen in love with fabrics like cotton, jersey, and stretchy blends. They’re soft, breathable, and easy to move in. That’s a game-changer when my muscles are feeling weak or stiff. A little stretch gives me the freedom to bend, sit, or stretch without feeling restricted.

content: And let’s be honest, who wants to feel suffocated by their clothes? Plus, I still manage to look put-together. No saggy pants here!

When my arms or hands are fatigued, dealing with buttons, zippers, or clasps feels like a battle. That’s when I look for easy-to-wear pieces like elastic waistbands, pullovers, and tops with no fastenings. These items are perfect for when I need to get dressed without breaking a sweat, yet still look polished and stylish.
I love how a loose tee or a dress that just slips on can create that effortlessly chic vibe I’m always after. And bonus points if it’s oversized – comfort and style in one!

As much as I love a good pair of heels, MG has definitely changed how I think about shoes. Unfortunately, no more strutting around in high heels, which used to be my go-to for nights out. Now, I go for shoes that combine support with style.

Brands have finally caught on to the fact that comfort doesn’t mean dowdy, and I’ve discovered orthopedic-inspired trainers (many Adidas trainers are actually orthotic-friendly; I live in my Adidas Astirs), slip-on loafers, and wedges/platform shoes. These shoes give me that extra lift when my legs are feeling weaker, but they don’t skimp on the fashion factor.

content: Temperature changes are another thing I’ve had to consider.

MG can make me sensitive to both heat and cold, so layering is a lifesaver. I’ve embraced light jackets, cardigans, and scarves as my go-to accessories. They’re easy to adjust as the day goes on, keeping me comfortable yet stylish no matter what the weather has in store.
And the best part? Layering adds that extra flair to an outfit, turning a simple look into something more polished with very little effort.

Living with MG can sometimes leave me feeling less than confident on tough days. But that’s where color and patterns come in. I’ve found that wearing something vibrant or fun can instantly boost my mood and energy.

A bold print, a pop of royal blue, or even a classic black-and-white combo can completely shift how I feel. Fashion isn’t just about looking good; it’s about feeling good, and I’ve realized wearing pieces that make me happy helps lift my spirits.

content: I’ve also developed a love for jewelry. This keeps me feeling put-together when my condition gets so bad I’m housebound. Slipping on fancy rings or a dazzling bracelet lifts my spirits. I get a lot of compliments on them.
And let’s not forget the power of getting your nails done. It’s one of the simplest ways to express yourself, whether you go for a bold color, an intricate design, or just a classic clean look.

A fresh manicure makes me feel put-together, even on my toughest days. It’s a fun way to add a personal touch to my style. Whether I’m feeling vibrant or calm, my nails are a reflection of my mood, giving me that extra boost of confidence.
The rise of adaptive fashion has also been a game-changer.

Brands are finally recognizing the importance of styles that are inclusive of all bodies and abilities. While I figured out how to adapt on my own, it’s refreshing to see clothing designed specifically for those with mobility or strength challenges.

content: Magnetic closures, adjustable hems, and easy-access pockets are just a few of the innovations that make dressing easier and more stylish. It’s amazing how fashion is becoming more functional, so you don’t have to sacrifice style for accessibility.
At the end of the day, fashion is all about embracing who you are and how you feel.

With MG, I’ve learned that style is about more than just aesthetics. It’s about making life easier and more enjoyable, and feeling fabulous while doing it. Whether I’m lounging at home, running errands, or meeting friends, I adapt my wardrobe to fit my energy levels and physical needs.
So, dress for you. Be comfortable, confident, and stylish in your own way. Life is too short not to wear what makes you feel like the best version of yourself.
